HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., FEBRUARY 12, 1929

Vol. XXXII', No. 30

BLUE JAY MERMAN
LOSE MEET TO NAM.
Black and Blue ,Swimmers Capture Only One First Place
--HISS IS OUTSTANDING

RIFLE TEAM TO MEET
GETTYSBURG FEB.61
On 'February 16, the rifle
team of Gettysburg College
will come here to shoot a
shoulder-to-shoulder match
with the Hopkins team, according to Captain Bass, of
the Mil i tar y Department,
coach of the local team. Last
year the Blue Jay team met
the Pennsylvanians at Gettysburg in a return match:lin
which it was victorious.

UNUSUAL INTERESTING GAME
CAUSES LONG NIGHT SESSION
.
The hour is late and all the campus lies bathed in the peace and
calm of inky blackness but, look!
A light still shines from the barn.
Can it be "Reds" Schaal burning the
midnight oil over some future campaign for reform or is it "Doc"
counting the accumulated "Shekals"
of a particularly fruitful day.
No, it is nothing less than the
gambling class holding its night
session.
Round the table nine or ten eager
hands reach for cards and the clink
of money resounds in the deserted
building.
At the end of the table stands the

banker dealing out the cards and
raking in the glittering coins while
by his side his cashier pays-,out to
those who clamor for payment. ,
Suddenly the door opens and all
eyes looki towards the newcomer,
perhaps expecting to see Sergeant
Frank, enforcing the law, but 'tis
only George the nightwatchman
come to see who is disturbing his
nightly vigil.
And so into the "wee sma' hours"
it goes. And only when the sky
begins to pale is the last of the
cards packed away and the crowd
disperses to snatch a few winks of
sleep before an eight-thirty.

FUTURE ASSEMBLIES
ARE ANNOUNCED
According to Donald Hiss,
President of the Student
Council, the following assemblies have been definitely
planned:
On February 14, the musical Club will provide entertainment, each group of the
club participating.
The Frosh-Soph debate will
be held two weeks from that
date. The subject of the debate has not been announced.
On March 14, Mr. Ernest
Rhys, editor'of the Everyman
Library, will speak.-. His topic
will be "George . Bernard
Shaw versus Shakespeare."
Garfield Hayes, who was a
participant in the Scopes trial
and who was a playmate of
Clarence Darrow, will speak
April 18. Mr. Hayes, who is
brought here by the Pi Lambda Phi fraternity, of which he
is a• member, has not announced his topic.

Price 5 Cents

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., FEBRUARY 12, 1929

Vol. XXXII', No. 30

BLUE JAY MERMAN
LOSE MEET TO NAM.
Black and Blue ,Swimmers Capture Only One First Place
--HISS IS OUTSTANDING

RIFLE TEAM TO MEET
GETTYSBURG FEB.61
On 'February 16, the rifle
team of Gettysburg College
will come here to shoot a
shoulder-to-shoulder match
with the Hopkins team, according to Captain Bass, of
the Mil i tar y Department,
coach of the local team. Last
year the Blue Jay team met
the Pennsylvanians at Gettysburg in a return match:lin
which it was victorious.

UNUSUAL INTERESTING GAME
CAUSES LONG NIGHT SESSION
.
The hour is late and all the campus lies bathed in the peace and
calm of inky blackness but, look!
A light still shines from the barn.
Can it be "Reds" Schaal burning the
midnight oil over some future campaign for reform or is it "Doc"
counting the accumulated "Shekals"
of a particularly fruitful day.
No, it is nothing less than the
gambling class holding its night
session.
Round the table nine or ten eager
hands reach for cards and the clink
of money resounds in the deserted
building.
At the end of the table stands the

banker dealing out the cards and
raking in the glittering coins while
by his side his cashier pays-,out to
those who clamor for payment. ,
Suddenly the door opens and all
eyes looki towards the newcomer,
perhaps expecting to see Sergeant
Frank, enforcing the law, but 'tis
only George the nightwatchman
come to see who is disturbing his
nightly vigil.
And so into the "wee sma' hours"
it goes. And only when the sky
begins to pale is the last of the
cards packed away and the crowd
disperses to snatch a few winks of
sleep before an eight-thirty.

FUTURE ASSEMBLIES
ARE ANNOUNCED
According to Donald Hiss,
President of the Student
Council, the following assemblies have been definitely
planned:
On February 14, the musical Club will provide entertainment, each group of the
club participating.
The Frosh-Soph debate will
be held two weeks from that
date. The subject of the debate has not been announced.
On March 14, Mr. Ernest
Rhys, editor'of the Everyman
Library, will speak.-. His topic
will be "George . Bernard
Shaw versus Shakespeare."
Garfield Hayes, who was a
participant in the Scopes trial
and who was a playmate of
Clarence Darrow, will speak
April 18. Mr. Hayes, who is
brought here by the Pi Lambda Phi fraternity, of which he
is a• member, has not announced his topic.
